verses.text: Do not judge, so that you will not be judged.
verses.comment: Jesus calls us to humility by warning against harsh judgment of others, reminding us that we ourselves are subject to God's judgment. This echoes Old Testament warnings against hypocritical judgment.

verses.text: For with the judgment you pronounce, you will be judged; and with the measure you use, it will be measured to you.
verses.comment: Here Jesus shows the justice and reciprocity of God's judgment. The measure we use with others is ultimately the measure returned to us. This points to the mercy we should strive for in our dealings—a crucial theological theme.

verses.text: Why do you look at the speck that is in your brother’s eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own eye?
verses.comment: Jesus uses a vivid metaphor to stress self-examination before criticizing others. The idea of our own 'log' points to the need for ongoing conversion and repentance.

verses.text: How can you say to your brother, ‘Let me take the speck out of your eye,’ while there is a log in your own eye?
verses.comment: The imagery underscores hypocrisy and invites us to humility and personal sanctity prior to correcting others—a foundation for authentic Christian community.

verses.text: You hypocrite, first take the log out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye.
verses.comment: Repentance prepares us to guide others rightly. Jesus’s order—cleansing ourselves before helping others—is echoed in many teachings about confession and spiritual growth.

verses.text: Do not give what is holy to dogs, and do not throw your pearls before pigs, lest they trample them underfoot and turn to attack you.
verses.comment: Jesus distinguishes between sacred truths and those not ready to receive them, suggesting wisdom in sharing deeper spiritual mysteries. In early Christianity, this was applied to the discipline of who received sacraments.

verses.text: Ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to you.
verses.comment: Jesus encourages persistent prayer and trust in God’s generosity. The active verbs ('ask, seek, knock') point to continual communion with God, and a sacramental understanding of God's gifts.

verses.text: For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be opened.
verses.comment: God’s fidelity is assured to those who earnestly seek Him. This highlights God's initiative and grace in salvation, connecting to gifts imparted in the Christian life.

verses.text: Or which one of you, if his son asks him for bread, will give him a stone?
verses.comment: Jesus uses parental love to illustrate God’s goodness, reinforcing the trustworthiness of God’s promises and care.

verses.text: Or if he asks for a fish, will give him a serpent?
verses.comment: Another instance of God’s good gifts, contrasted with the unlikely scenario of a loving father giving harm instead of nourishment.

verses.text: If you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask Him!
verses.comment: This teaching presents God as the source of all goodness, emphasizing His fatherly nature. Early Christians saw the 'good things' as spiritual graces and gifts administered through the Church.

verses.text: So whatever you wish that others would do to you, do also to them; for this is the Law and the Prophets.
verses.comment: The 'Golden Rule' summarizes moral teaching in the Old Testament, and places love and mercy at the center of Christian living—a key for unity among believers.

verses.text: Enter by the narrow gate. For the gate is wide and the way is easy that leads to destruction, and those who enter by it are many.
verses.comment: Jesus implies exclusivity and discipline in salvation, not universalism. The 'narrow gate' suggests obedience and perseverance, which the early Church guarded through clear teaching and sacramental participation.

verses.text: For the gate is narrow and the way is hard that leads to life, and those who find it are few.
verses.comment: Salvation, though offered to all, requires effort and grace. The concept of a 'way' echoes the idea of walking a path and undergoing conversion as a process.

verses.text: Beware of false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing but inwardly are ravenous wolves.
verses.comment: Jesus warns about deceptive teachers. The imagery is reminiscent of Old Testament prophecy. The authority to discern true doctrine is key to safeguarding the flock.

verses.text: You will recognize them by their fruits. Are grapes gathered from thornbushes, or figs from thistles?
verses.comment: True doctrine and holiness lead to good works ('fruits'). The Church has long identified authenticity by the lives of its teachers—a spiritual principle for discerning truth.

verses.text: So, every healthy tree bears good fruit, but the diseased tree bears bad fruit.
verses.comment: A life rooted in Christ naturally produces virtue. Spiritual health comes from union with God, as maintained by faithful participation in Christian living.

verses.text: A healthy tree cannot bear bad fruit, nor can a diseased tree bear good fruit.
verses.comment: The necessity of grace and ongoing transformation is reflected here—goodness is not mere effort but comes from being spiritually renewed.

verses.text: Every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.
verses.comment: A clear warning of judgment. The cutting down of fruitless trees symbolizes spiritual consequences and the reality of eternal choices.

verses.text: Thus you will recognize them by their fruits.
verses.comment: Repetition underscores the importance of discernment. Authentic faith is always verified by its visible impact and spiritual integrity.

verses.text: Not everyone who says to me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ will enter the kingdom of heaven, but only the one who does the will of my Father who is in heaven.
verses.comment: A striking claim of Jesus’s authority—only those who truly obey enter the kingdom. This underlines the necessity of both faith and faithful living, as held in Christian tradition.

verses.text: On that day many will say to me, ‘Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and cast out demons in your name, and do many mighty works in your name?’
verses.comment: Jesus places Himself as judge in the Last Day—a claim of divine prerogative. External works alone do not suffice; genuine relationship and transformation are key.

verses.text: And then I will declare to them, ‘I never knew you; depart from me, you workers of lawlessness.’
verses.comment: Jesus' authority to judge and exclude points to His divine role. Knowing Christ personally is foundational, not merely performing religious works. This anticipates a clear distinction between outward practice and true discipleship.

verses.text: Everyone who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock.
verses.comment: Here Jesus equates obedience to His teaching with building upon a firm foundation—a metaphor rich in Old Testament meaning, often identified with faithfulness and security in God.

verses.text: And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat upon that house, but it did not fall, because it had been founded on the rock.
verses.comment: The storm testifies to challenges and trials; a life grounded in Christ’s teaching and grace stands firm. Early Christians saw this as an analogy for faithful perseverance within the communion of believers.

verses.text: And everyone who hears these words of mine and does not do them will be like a foolish man who built his house on the sand.
verses.comment: Not all who hear belong to God; true wisdom is shown by obedience, not merely acknowledgment. The foundation determines the destiny.

verses.text: And the rain fell, and the floods came, and the winds blew and beat upon that house, and it fell—and great was its fall.
verses.comment: Concludes the parable with a stern warning about the consequences of rejecting or neglecting Christ’s commands—echoing Old Testament imagery of judgment and ruin.

verses.text: And when Jesus finished these words, the crowds were amazed at His teaching,
verses.comment: The people's awe at Jesus’ teaching underscores His unique authority and wisdom, fulfilling the prophetic expectation of a teacher greater than Moses (cf. Deut. 18:15).

verses.text: for He was teaching them as one who had authority, and not as their scribes.
verses.comment: Jesus’ authority was divine and personal, not derivative as with the scribes. This points to His unique relationship with the Father and His role as the final revealer of God’s will.
